Posts.Content: cabmom wrote: Hi ladies....me again.  Just wondering if anyone out there has had a lumpectomy, they didn't get clear enough margins twice and then just decided instead of letting them go in to get a little more went with a mastectomy instead.  I'm so tired of the ups and downs of this just not sure what the answer is at this point.  Do I just get more clearance or take it all?  Can anyone shed some light on this if they've been in a similar situation.  I've already been through a double lumpectomy, additional surgery for a clearer margin on the upper inner quad and now they need to either go back in for a clearer margin on the lower quad or just take it all.  At this point......I'm thinking what is the point of keeping something that has already produced two tumors but at the same time, thinking I've come so far to save it....... I'm also still waiting to see what my 2nd MRI will show on my other breast that was written up as "indeterminable" in one state and now the doctors here have said that's not an acceptable answer when dealing with cancer....... Any suggestions.......  Dx 6/2/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 0/16 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Surgery Again or what? cabmom Lilah

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2009 08:07PM cabmom wrote: Thanks all.....I have infiltrating ductal carcinoma.  Both of the lumpectomy has clear margins but the lower inner quad doesn't have but 1mm which is not comfortable for the radiologist oncologist to feel that he can get the entire area and not put me back at risk for recurrence.....such a confusing time plus I am still waiting on my results from the 2nd MRI.......just ready to move on and get my life back.  I know that each and every one of you has probably felt the very same way....
Posts.Title: Surgery Again or what? cabmom Lilah

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2009 02:26PM cabmom wrote: lisalisa, I saw in your post that you use Biotin from Whole Foods.  Does it matter what manufacturer or milligrams you take?  I've seen a lot of posts on here that it works and your post definitely caught my eye.  I'm suppose to begin chemo the first week in November and really dreading any hair loss......thanks for the advice.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2009 11:22AM cabmom wrote: Thanks to all the wonderful replies and I know that I will be okay.  Went yesterday for my final decision to the medical oncologist and set up my appointments, then 1 hour later to the radiation oncologist that informed me that my margins might not be clear enough for radiation.  I may be back to the operating room before I begin anything.....it was another really hard day.  I was pretty upset but today I am just ready to go back to the surgeon and see what the options are this time.  Wish me luck, my appointment will be this coming Friday with her.....I'm just so ready to be done with this and get my life back.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2009 10:28AM cabmom wrote: Good morning ladies and I'm new to this thread.  I've enjoyed reading all your posts and only wish I was where all of you are with your hair growing back.  I am getting ready to begin chemo in the next couple weeks and am so scared of losing my hair.  I know that it's really a silly thought and being healthy is the only thing I should be focused on but I just can't seem to get passed these feelings.  Were all of you scared as well and will these feelings get better?  There are days that I feel as though I'm going to have a nervous breakdown......how did you guys get to the point you are now?  I need help and advise on how to get through this.  I have a little boy I want to see grow up and without doing chemo, I'm afraid that I won't be able to.  Any advice?
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2011 07:37AM cabmom wrote: jdeking, thank you for your response.  My onc really scared me to death with the whole uterine cancer thing.  Since I'm done having children and if I make it through all my tests today without anything being wrong, I am considering a permanent solution with a hysterectomy.  Just think it might eliminate some unnecessary worry's.  Do you also have to have pelvic ultrasounds?  Praying that today goes okay.
Posts.Title: Chemo induced menopause cabmom Pegs

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2011 01:54PM cabmom wrote: Ladies, thanks to all for the responses.  Unfortunately, I won't get the results back until the middle of next week but if when they come back, if it is not uterine cancer then I am going to take my time to make my decision.  I know there are advantages to a hysterectomy but I'm not sure they outweigh the benefits of not.  Just a lot to think and pray about.  My onc made such a huge deal out of me having my period again and now I've found out that lots of women have their periods again after chemo and all of them are on Tamoxifen.......it's just a little confusing why they have to try to scare us into a decision NOW.  Lena, I can only imagine how badly it stinks, can they give you anything to counter the effects some?  I've had people tell me that they can but not sure how that interacts with breast cancer....hope it gets better as time goes on....
Posts.Title: Chemo induced menopause cabmom Pegs

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2011 07:01PM cabmom wrote: Ladies, I am so happy to report that my biopsy came back today :) and it showed no signs of uterine cancer.  Can't hardly stop smiling....so happy they came back so quickly, definitely a nice surprise!  Since there is no cancer, then I am going to take my time on deciding about what to do next.....hysterectomy or not, etc.
Posts.Title: Chemo induced menopause cabmom Pegs

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2011 08:18PM cabmom wrote: nikola, If I don't choose to have a hysterectomy, I will definitely stay on Tamoxifen and just be closely monitored because of the thickening.  I don't feel I have any choice about that.

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2011 06:13AM cabmom wrote: Just a quick update, after testing yesterday, it's determined that Tamoxifen is causing issues with my uterine and now I'm awaiting biopsy results.  Praying for good news but it will be next week before the results come in.  I'm sure there are more decisions that I'll be making which I'm dreading but I know it will be okay.
Posts.Title: Chemo induced menopause cabmom Pegs

Posts.Content: cabmom wrote: Question for any ladies that were pre-menopausal before chemo.......if chemo stopped your periods and put you in menopause, have any of you started your periods back and come out of menopause?  Is this a huge concern?  Does anyone have any advice? Dx 6/2/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 0/16 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2011 05:46AM cabmom wrote: Thanks everyone.  I was also 43 when diagnosed in 09 and hadn't had a period since Dec 09 but started back a couple days ago.  Think I'm just in shock.  My onc did warn me that there were no guarantees that it wouldn't come back.  Since it has, because of the Tamoxifen have to rule out uterine cancer so more tests.  I'm praying that it's just my body wanting to be normal again.
